title: Yelets
text:
Yelets, or Elets (), is a <a href="types%20of%20inhabited%20localities%20in%20Russia">city</a> in <a href="Lipetsk%20Oblast">Lipetsk Oblast</a>, <a href="Russia">Russia</a>, situated on the <a href="Bystraya%20Sosna%20River">Bystraya Sosna River</a>, which is a tributary of the <a href="Don%20River%2C%20Russia">Don</a>. Population: 
History.
Yelets is the oldest center of the <a href="Central%20Black%20Earth%20Region">Central Black Earth Region</a>. It was mentioned in historical documents as early as 1146 or 1147, when it was a fort belonging to the Princes of <a href="Ryazan">Ryazan</a>. The town's position at the very south of Russian lands made it an easy prey for Turkic conquerors. The <a href="Mongols">Mongols</a> burned it in 1239, <a href="Uzbeg%20Khan">Uzbeg Khan</a> ravaged it in 1316, <a href="Timur">Timur</a> sacked it in 1395, and the <a href="Tatars">Tatars</a> devastated it in 1414.
In 1483, the Principality of Yelets was absorbed by the <a href="Grand%20Duchy%20of%20Moscow">Grand Duchy of Moscow</a>, while the local <a href="Rurik%20Dynasty">Rurikid</a> rulers (last heard of in the 19th century) entered the service of <a href="Ivan%20III%20of%20Russia">Ivan III</a>. In 1591, <a href="Boris%20Godunov">Boris Godunov</a> revived the largely deserted town by establishing a fortress there. In 1618, the fortress was captured "by subterfuge" by 20,000 <a href="Cossacks">Cossacks</a> under <a href="Petro%20Konashevych-Sahaidachny">Petro Konashevych-Sahaidachny</a>, allied with <a href="W%C5%82adys%C5%82aw%20IV%20Vasa">Władysław IV</a> of <a href="Poland">Poland</a>. They dismantled a large part of town fortifications.
In the 19th century, Yelets became the largest trade center of the region. Handmade <a href="lace">lace</a> has been a notable product of the city since then; other important industries are grain milling and the manufacture of machinery. The town's chief landmark is the vast Ascension Cathedral, built over the years 1845–1889 to a Neo-Muscovite design by <a href="Konstantin%20Thon">Konstantin Thon</a>. The town was occupied by the <a href="Wehrmacht">German Army</a> from December 4 to 9, 1941 and damaged during the brief occupation and Soviet offensive in the region.
Administrative and municipal status.
Within the <a href="subdivisions%20of%20Russia%23Administrative%20divisions">framework of administrative divisions</a>, Yelets serves as the <a href="administrative%20center">administrative center</a> of <a href="Yeletsky%20District">Yeletsky District</a>, even though it is not a part of it. As an administrative division, it is incorporated as Yelets <a href="City%20of%20federal%20subject%20significance">City Under Oblast Jurisdiction</a>—an administrative unit with a status equal to that of the <a href="administrative%20divisions%20of%20Lipetsk%20Oblast">districts</a>. As a <a href="subdivisions%20of%20Russia%23Municipal%20divisions">municipal division</a>, Yelets City Under Oblast Jurisdiction is incorporated as Yelets Urban Okrug.
Economy and transportation.
The city is connected to <a href="Moscow">Moscow</a>, <a href="Lipetsk">Lipetsk</a>, <a href="Oryol">Oryol</a>, and <a href="Rostov">Rostov</a> by rail and the <a href="M4%20highway%20%28Russia%29">M4 highway</a> runs past it.
The main industries are limestone quarrying, engineering, food processing, textiles and clothing (Yelets Lace), tobacco processing, and vodka distilling.
Culture and education.
The city has a theatre, cinemas, and several sports venues.
The Yelets State University was upgraded from an institute in 2000 and the city has eight secondary schools.
